riyadhPage.heroSubtitle: A modern metropolis blending tradition and innovation at the heart of the Kingdom.
riyadhPage.section1Title: Riyadh – The Beating Heart of the Kingdom
riyadhPage.section1Para1: Riyadh's roots extend to the oases of Najd and its historic cities, where the spark of unification was ignited from Diriyah, then Riyadh flourished as a modern capital combining the authenticity of the place with rapid urban, economic, and cultural momentum.
riyadhPage.section1Para2: The city has embraced state institutions and decision-making centers, and developed its infrastructure, public spaces, and cultural destinations, while preserving the characteristics of Najdi hospitality and local architectural identity.
riyadhPage.section1Para3: Today, Riyadh offers an integrated urban experience: international events, museums, major parks, and a diverse culinary scene, alongside heritage neighborhoods that have been revived to tell the city's story across the ages.
riyadhPage.section1Para4: Urban enhancement programs continue to improve quality of life through green projects, pedestrian paths, modern public transport, and digital services for guidance and navigation.
riyadhPage.section1Item1: Historic Diriyah and At-Turaif District (World Heritage Site)
riyadhPage.section1Item4: Seasonal Events and Cultural and Artistic Scene
riyadhPage.section2Para1: Diriyah is considered the cradle of the Saudi state and a showcase of Najdi architecture; in its surroundings, Wadi Hanifa extends with its gardens, paths, and bridges, forming an open park for strolling, walking, and cycling.
riyadhPage.section2Para2: The area combines cultural and architectural content with restaurants and cafes overlooking the valley, in addition to illuminated paths and informative panels that enrich the visitor's experience.
riyadhPage.section2Para3: Services are integrated through organized parking, paths prepared for families and the elderly, with digital guidance and directions for events and specialized exhibitions.
riyadhPage.section2Para4: The site's environmental systems are respected by maintaining cleanliness and tranquility, and not harming vegetation or historical terrain.
riyadhPage.section2Item1: At-Turaif District — Mud architecture and exhibition paths
riyadhPage.section2Item3: Pedestrian paths on the banks of Wadi Hanifa
riyadhPage.section3Subtitle: Facilitated Access, Smart Services, and Balanced Urban Experience
riyadhPage.section3Para1: The city is connected to the world via King Khalid International Airport, and is preparing with a modern public transport system being gradually operated, with ring roads and connecting axes ensuring smooth movement between its neighborhoods and main hubs.
riyadhPage.section3Para2: Riyadh thrives with parks, urban gardens, pedestrian paths, and major green projects, alongside cultural facilities and urban fronts that accommodate international events.
riyadhPage.section3Para3: Smart applications and interactive maps support visit planning, route selection, and updates on events, restaurants, and museums.
riyadhPage.section3Para4: The hospitality, shopping, and entertainment options integrate to offer a world-class city experience with the character of a firmly established local identity.
riyadhPage.section3Item2: Modern public transport network and urban paths
riyadhPage.section4Para1: At-Turaif District offers an open-air museum experience, with exhibition paths and architectural components that introduce Najdi architecture and founding paths, with artistic and seasonal events that illuminate the district's courtyards and squares.
riyadhPage.section4Para2: It is recommended to book tickets early, wear appropriate walking shoes, and take advantage of guided tours and digital media available at the site.
riyadhPage.section5Title: Masmak Fort and Qasr Al-Hukm Area
riyadhPage.section5Para1: Masmak forms a prominent historical station in the heart of Riyadh; surrounded by squares, cultural platforms, and traditional markets, making the visit an opportunity to learn about the features of the old city and its commercial customs.
riyadhPage.section6Subtitle: Narrative of the Arabian Peninsula Across the Ages
riyadhPage.section6Para1: The National Museum displays paths that trace the history of the Arabian Peninsula, from ancient times to the Saudi state, and is adjacent to the Al-Murabba complex with Najdi architecture, spacious gardens, and periodic exhibitions.
riyadhPage.section7Para1: A vibrant entertainment destination hosting seasonal events, restaurants, cafes, shops, and interactive experiences, with performance platforms and open-air theaters.
riyadhPage.section8Subtitle: Architectural Horizon and Modern Business Scene
riyadhPage.section8Para1: KAFD stands out with its towers, architectural designs, and public spaces, hosting financial institutions, companies, and hospitality options, with prepared pedestrian paths and public art that enrich the urban scene.
riyadhPage.section9Subtitle: Urban Breathing Space and Family Paths
riyadhPage.section9Para1: Provides green spaces, pedestrian paths, and play areas, with fountain shows and service facilities that make it a family choice for quiet time in the heart of the city.
riyadhPage.section10Para1: At a distance from the city, the 'Edge of the World' offers a panoramic view of valleys and rock formations. It is recommended to visit with a specialized guide and suitable vehicle, bring water and safety equipment, and follow the site's instructions.

makkahPage.heroSubtitle: The heart of Islam and the sacred destination of Hajj and Umrah.
makkahPage.section1Title: Makkah Al-Mukarramah – The First Destination for Muslims
makkahPage.section1Para1: Makkah Al-Mukarramah is one of the oldest cities in the Arabian Peninsula; it has maintained its religious and commercial status over the centuries, then became the qibla of Muslims and the destination of hearts and a center of knowledge and hospitality with the dawn of Islam.
makkahPage.section1Para2: Makkah has undergone extensive development and organization phases affecting the Grand Mosque, its courtyards, facilities, and road networks, making the Umrah and visit experience easier throughout the year while maintaining the privacy and sanctity of the place.
makkahPage.section1Para3: While the pace of urban and service development accelerates, the city maintains its authentic spirit and hospitable traditions, where historical landmarks coexist with modern projects that serve millions of visitors.
makkahPage.section1Para4: Today, Makkah offers a balanced experience combining spiritual tranquility with operational efficiency, within a smart service system for crowd management, guidance, and transportation.
makkahPage.section1Item1: The Grand Mosque and the Kaaba
makkahPage.section1Item5: King Abdulaziz Complex for Kaaba Kiswah
makkahPage.section2Subtitle: The Heart of Makkah and Qibla of Muslims
makkahPage.section2Para1: The Grand Mosque is the holiest place in Islam, and the Kaaba occupies a central position since the earliest ages of humanity. The hearts and bodies of Muslims turn to it in prayers, and millions of pilgrims and Umrah performers visit it annually to perform rituals in a spiritual atmosphere full of faith and tranquility. Visiting the Grand Mosque is restricted to Muslims only.
makkahPage.section2Highlights: Prominent Landmarks of the Grand Mosque
makkahPage.section2Item1Desc: The holiest house in Islam, around which Muslims perform seven circuits throughout the year.
makkahPage.section2Item2Desc: A stone from Paradise located in the eastern corner of the Kaaba, from which the Tawaf begins.
makkahPage.section2Item3Desc: An authentic corner from the building of Abraham (peace be upon him), and it is recommended to touch it during Tawaf.
makkahPage.section2Item4Desc: A stone bearing the footprint of Prophet Abraham while building the Kaaba.
makkahPage.section2Item5Desc: A semi-circular area that was part of the Kaaba in the old building.
makkahPage.section2Item6Desc: The place of Sa'i between Safa and Marwah following the Sa'i of Lady Hagar in search of water.
makkahPage.section2Item7Desc: A miraculous well that has been flowing since the time of Hagar (peace be upon her), and its water is available in the Haram through containers and drinking fountains.
makkahPage.section2Item8Desc: The Haram includes 13 beautiful minarets from which the call to prayer is made.
makkahPage.section2Item9Desc: A modern marble pulpit designed with high precision and used for Friday sermons.
makkahPage.section2Item10Desc: It includes more than 210 gates to facilitate visitor movement and reduce crowding.
makkahPage.section3Subtitle: A Connected Journey Between Makkah, Mina, Muzdalifah, and Arafat
makkahPage.section3Para1: The Sacred Sites host the pillars and major rites of Hajj, where hospitality, transportation, and guidance services are integrated to ensure smooth movement for millions of pilgrims and Umrah performers during the seasons. Visitor movement is managed through modern transportation systems including shuttle buses and the Haramain High-Speed Railway, with pedestrian paths and guidance centers that enhance flow and safety.
makkahPage.section3Para2: Health, emergency, and digital support services are also widely spread to ensure a safe and organized spiritual journey, while the sanctity of the place and respect for environmental and behavioral regulations remain an integral part of the Hajj experience.
makkahPage.section3Highlights: Key Stations in the Sacred Sites
makkahPage.section3Item1Desc: Prepared camps providing a safe and comfortable environment with accommodation and air conditioning services.
makkahPage.section3Item2Desc: Gradual and multi-level organization to ensure smooth flow and reduce crowding.
makkahPage.section3Item3Desc: Mount of Mercy and spacious courtyards that receive millions of pilgrims on the Day of Arafat.
makkahPage.section3Item4Desc: The site of the Day of Arafat sermon and extensive facilities to accommodate crowds.
makkahPage.section3Item5Desc: Overnight stay after Ifadah and collecting pebbles in preparation for the Days of Tashreeq.
makkahPage.section3Item6Desc: A fast transportation means connecting Mina, Muzdalifah, and Arafat, reducing crowding.
makkahPage.section3Item7Desc: Guidance in multiple languages and field support to serve pilgrims.
makkahPage.section3Item8Desc: Clinics and ambulances ready around the clock to deal with emergency cases.
makkahPage.section4Para1: Jabal Al-Nour is one of the most important places in the history of Islam and the biography of its Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him); it is located northeast of the Grand Mosque at a distance of four kilometers, and at the top of the mountain from the southwestern side is Hira Cave, where the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to seclude himself for worship before the mission; and in it, revelation came to him.
makkahPage.section4Para2: The path is mountainous and requires moderate fitness and simple equipment; it is recommended to visit the site during moderate times to avoid heat and crowding.
makkahPage.section4Para3: Visitors are keen to maintain the cleanliness of the place and respect its sanctity, and adhere to safety and organization instructions.
makkahPage.section4TipsText: Wear appropriate shoes, bring sufficient water, follow field instructions and digital maps, and avoid peak hours if possible.
makkahPage.section5Subtitle: A blessed water well located in the Grand Mosque
makkahPage.section5Para1: Zamzam Well is a well located in the Grand Mosque in Makkah Al-Mukarramah near the Kaaba, from which Zamzam water flows, which the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) described as blessed water, and explained that it is a cure for diseases.
makkahPage.section6Title: King Abdulaziz Complex for Kaaba Kiswah
makkahPage.section6Subtitle: The place where the Kaaba covering is made
makkahPage.section6Para1: The complex is located in Umm Al-Joud area in Makkah, and it is the place where the Kaaba covering (Kiswah) is manufactured with the finest materials and highest craftsmanship, reflecting the care and attention given to the holiest place in Islam.
makkahPage.section7Subtitle: From Arrival to Departure — A Complete Guest Experience
makkahPage.section7Para1: Access options to Makkah vary between fast connection via the Haramain High-Speed Railway, nearby airports, and modern road networks, with large external parking and efficient shuttle transportation to the Haram area.
makkahPage.section7Para2: The city boasts a global hospitality system and precise operational standards, including spacious courtyards, pedestrian tunnels, and contemporary architectural facades surrounding the Grand Mosque.
makkahPage.section7Para3: The experience is supported by digital services for guidance, crowd management, interactive maps, and real-time updates that facilitate movement and choice.
makkahPage.section7Para4: Makkah's message remains hospitality and tranquility; welcoming its visitors throughout the year with continuous care for guest comfort and dignity.
makkahPage.section7Item2: Kudi stations and external parking with shuttle buses
makkahPage.section7Item3: Pedestrian tunnels and spacious courtyards around the Haram
makkahPage.section7Item5: Digital guidance services and interactive maps
makkahPage.event1Title: The International Fairs and Museums of the Prophet's Biography and Islamic Civilization
makkahPage.event1Description: An immersive cultural exhibition showcasing the life of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ through interactive halls, models, and digital experiences. A ticketed museum-style event designed to educate visitors about Islamic history. Suitable for families and tourists.
makkahPage.event2Description: A guided tour around key historical sites in Makkah with panoramic viewpoints and storytelling. Includes visits to places like Jabal Khadijah and the Tree Mosque. Tickets required and booked as a full experience.
makkahPage.event3Description: A cultural festival with shows, exhibits, and family activities celebrating Makkah's heritage. Hosted in the Hira Cultural District with organized entry through tickets. Popular during holidays and seasonal events.

madinahPage.heroSubtitle: A sacred city and home to Al-Masjid an-Nabawi, the Prophet's Mosque.
madinahPage.section1Para1: It is distinguished by exceptional and spiritual atmospheres, where visitors from all over the world come to pray in the Prophet's Mosque, and feel tranquility and peace in every corner. In addition to the spiritual atmospheres, visitors can enjoy tours of archaeological sites that tell the city's ancient history.
madinahPage.section1Para2: The city has undergone organized urban expansions that preserved its authenticity, and extended to the courtyards of the Prophet's Mosque, its facilities, road networks, and guidance, making movement and flow easier for visitors throughout the year.
madinahPage.section1Para3: Today, the city combines the spirituality of the place and smart service systems; from transportation, hospitality, and interactive maps to crowd management and quality of life for residents and visitors.
madinahPage.section1Para4: Development projects continue to enhance the human and faith experience, while preserving and reviving historical sites with cultural and knowledge content.
madinahPage.section1Item1: The Prophet's Mosque and the Rawdah
madinahPage.section1Item2: Quba Mosque — The first mosque established in Islam
madinahPage.section1Item4: Qiblatain Mosque and the Trench site (Mount Sela)
madinahPage.section2Subtitle: Quba, Qiblatain, the Trench, and Miqat Dhu Al-Hulaifah
madinahPage.section2Para1: Around the Prophet's Mosque extend faith sites that tell chapters of the biography: Quba, Qiblatain, Mount Sela (the Trench site), and Miqat Dhu Al-Hulaifah (Abyar Ali). Guidance, transportation, and hospitality services are integrated to ensure a calm and organized experience.
madinahPage.section2Para2: Pedestrian paths, external parking, and shuttle transportation are available, with bilingual information panels and instructions regarding general behavior and respect for the privacy of historical neighborhoods.
madinahPage.section2Para3: The experience is supported by digital guidance applications to determine peak times and the best routes, and provide reliable information about sites and their impact on Islamic history.
madinahPage.section2Para4: Modest dress is observed, maintaining the cleanliness of sites, and not obstructing the movement of worshippers and visitors.
madinahPage.section2Item1: Quba Mosque — Visit and pray two rak'ahs
madinahPage.section2Item2: Qiblatain Mosque — The story of changing the qibla
madinahPage.section2Item4: Miqat Dhu Al-Hulaifah (Abyar Ali) — Ihram for Umrah
madinahPage.section2Item6: Shuttle transportation solutions and peripheral parking
madinahPage.section3Para1: The Messenger of God (peace be upon him) built his noble mosque when he arrived in Madinah as an emigrant from Makkah after building Quba Mosque, and the mosque witnessed several expansions throughout history; the first expansion was during his time (peace be upon him) in the seventh year of Hijrah, then during the time of Umar bin Al-Khattab in 17 AH, and Uthman bin Affan in 29 AH, and the first rulers and governors from successive Islamic states gave it their attention and care, and several repairs and expansions were carried out during the reign of King Abdulaziz bin Abdulrahman Al Saud and his sons, the kings, which are the largest in the history of the architecture of the Prophet's Mosque.
madinahPage.section3Para2: It is recommended to visit during moderate times and follow pedestrian paths and guidance panels, while maintaining the cleanliness of the site.
madinahPage.section4Subtitle: A majestic mountain with a special place for our noble Messenger, as he (peace be upon him) said: (Uhud is a mountain that loves us and we love it).
madinahPage.section4Para1: One of the greatest battles of Islam took place near it, which is the Battle of Uhud, in which 70 of the Companions were martyred, including the Master of Martyrs, Hamzah bin Abdul Muttalib (may God be pleased with him). And the Messenger of God (peace be upon him) often used it as an example of great size, such as his saying in praise of his Companions: 'By the One in whose hand is my soul, if one of you spent the like of Uhud in gold, it would not reach a mudd of one of them nor half of it.'
madinahPage.section4Para2: It is recommended to visit during moderate times and follow pedestrian paths and guidance panels, while maintaining the cleanliness of the site.
madinahPage.section5Subtitle: The first mosque built in Islam
madinahPage.section5Para1: The first mosque built in Islam, our Prophet laid its foundation stone with his noble hands, and the Muhajireen and Ansar raised its structure, and God showed its virtue with a Quran that is recited until the Day of Judgment: 'A mosque founded on piety from the first day is more worthy for you to stand in.' The greatest mosque in Islam after the three mosques, located in the lands of Bani Amr bin Awf of the Ansar, today it is connected to the Prophet's Mosque by a pedestrian path extending 3 km, which the people of Madinah and its visitors frequent for prayer and worship, following the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and seeking reward.
madinahPage.section6Para1: The mosque is located northwest of Madinah, close to Al-Aqiq, known as the Mosque of Bani Salimah because it is located in their lands, and they are a branch of the Ansar, then it was named Qiblatain Mosque because the Prophet (peace be upon him) came to their area and prayed with them, and it happened that the command came to change from Bayt Al-Maqdis to the Kaaba while he was standing praying Dhuhr as an imam with his companions, so he prayed with the Muslims two rak'ahs facing Bayt Al-Maqdis, then completed the remaining two rak'ahs facing the Grand Mosque, making this mosque one of the monuments witnessing one of the most important events in Muslim history.
madinahPage.section7Subtitle: Facilitated Access and Integrated Service System
madinahPage.section7Para1: The city is connected via Prince Mohammad bin Abdulaziz International Airport, the Haramain High-Speed Railway, and a network of ring roads and tunnels that facilitate access to the courtyards surrounding the Prophet's Mosque.
madinahPage.section7Para2: The giant canopies in the courtyards remain a model of climate-controlled engineering and spaciousness, with organized pedestrian paths, waiting areas, and services for the elderly and people with disabilities.
madinahPage.section7Para3: Smart applications and interactive maps support decision-making during visit times and movement between sites, with real-time updates on crowd movement.
madinahPage.section7Para4: The city abounds with diverse hospitality options, heritage markets, and local kitchens that enhance the guest experience and appeal to their taste.
madinahPage.section7Item2: Prince Mohammad bin Abdulaziz Airport (Modern Terminal)
madinahPage.section7Item3: Shaded courtyards around the Prophet's Mosque

madinahPage.event2Description: A guided heritage tour through Al-Madinah's historical and sacred sites offering insight into Islamic history and local heritage.
madinahPage.event3Title: The International Fair & Museum of the Prophet's Biography – Al‑Madinah
madinahPage.event3Description: An immersive museum-exhibition next to the Prophet's Mosque, using modern tech (VR/3D) to explore the life and teachings of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ.

jeddahPage.heroSubtitle: A vibrant coastal city blending ancient history with modern luxury on the Red Sea.
jeddahPage.section1Title: Jeddah – Gateway to the Red Sea
jeddahPage.section1Para1: Jeddah has been a major port city for centuries, serving as the gateway to Makkah for pilgrims from around the world. The city combines rich historical heritage with modern development, creating a unique blend of tradition and innovation.
jeddahPage.section1Para2: The historic Al-Balad district, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, showcases stunning coral stone architecture, while the modern Corniche stretches along the Red Sea coast, offering beautiful waterfront views and recreational activities.
jeddahPage.section1Para3: Today, Jeddah is a cosmopolitan hub known for its vibrant arts scene, world-class dining, and cultural festivals that celebrate both local traditions and international influences.
jeddahPage.section1Item5: Red Sea diving and marine activities
jeddahPage.section2Subtitle: Extended promenade, trails, and marine activities
jeddahPage.section2Para1: Jeddah Corniche extends with walking and cycling paths, open gardens, and children's play areas, with sea-view platforms, boat marinas, and restaurants overlooking the waterfront.
jeddahPage.section2Para2: Art installations, fountains, and seasonal event areas are distributed along the Corniche, alongside seating stations, pedestrian crossings, and facility services that enhance visitor comfort.
jeddahPage.section2Para3: The Corniche is also integrated with commercial areas, international restaurants, and cafes with sea views, creating a complete stroll experience for families and visitors.
jeddahPage.section2Para4: Smart parking solutions and traffic management are available to enable smooth access and crowd distribution during peak seasons.
jeddahPage.section2Item3: Restaurants and cafes overlooking the sea
jeddahPage.section3Subtitle: Easy access, smart services, and vibrant experience
jeddahPage.section3Para1: Jeddah is connected to the world via King Abdulaziz International Airport, and to neighboring cities via the Haramain High-Speed Railway and modern circular road networks.
jeddahPage.section3Para2: The city welcomes its visitors with hotels, resorts, and major shopping centers, alongside modern neighborhoods and public spaces that humanize the urban experience.
jeddahPage.section3Para3: Digital services enhance guidance, transportation, and choice, with interactive maps and updates for events and activities.
jeddahPage.section3Para4: Public arts and cultural programs are integrated in shaping the city's identity and contemporary maritime character.
jeddahPage.section3Item2: Haramain Railway — Jeddah Airport and Madinah stations
jeddahPage.section3Item3: Circular roads and access axes to the Corniche
jeddahPage.section3Item5: Artistic and cultural events throughout the year
jeddahPage.section4Para1: Al-Balad preserves the features of old Jeddah: stone houses and decorated Roshan windows, alleys, and ancient markets that tell the story of the sea, trade, and hospitality.
jeddahPage.section4Para2: Among historical houses such as Nasseef House, cafes, and renewed squares, visitors will find a living cultural experience where memory coexists with artistic performances and festivals.
jeddahPage.section4Para3: It is recommended to visit in the evening for moderate weather and bustling activity, while adhering to guidelines for preserving heritage sites.
jeddahPage.section4TipsText: Wear comfortable shoes, explore the alleys leisurely, take advantage of guided tours, and document the experience with photos while respecting residents' privacy.
jeddahPage.section5Subtitle: An icon on the Red Sea coast
jeddahPage.section5Para1: The fountain is a visual landmark at night, viewable from several points on the Corniche; surrounded by seating areas, promenade, and open sea views.
jeddahPage.section6Subtitle: An open garden for contemporary art
jeddahPage.section6Para1: The open museum houses sculptural works by international and local artists along the Corniche, making the stroll a cultural and scenic experience at the same time.
jeddahPage.section7Para1: Al-Rahmah Mosque is one of Jeddah's most famous maritime landmarks; its white domes blend with the blue of the sea, offering visitors spiritual moments on the water's surface.
jeddahPage.section8Subtitle: The Artistic and Coastal Pulse of Jeddah
jeddahPage.section8Para1: The Art Promenade (Jeddah Art Promenade) is a contemporary icon on Jeddah's waterfront, brilliantly blending the enchanting view of the Red Sea with modern art. The promenade features open-air art installations, spaces for live events and drone shows, alongside luxurious restaurants and cafes. It is an integrated destination offering entertainment, culture, and contemplation in the heart of the city.
jeddahPage.section9Para1: From major shopping centers to local and international restaurants, Jeddah offers a wide variety of culinary options; from fresh fish to international cuisines, in family-friendly atmospheres throughout the city.
jeddahPage.section10Para1: Jeddah hosts artistic and sports events throughout the year, with theaters, outdoor platforms, and celebration areas, making each visit renewed in every season.
jeddahPage.event1Description: The World Rally Championship returns to Jeddah, showcasing elite drivers, thrilling stages, and high-speed excitement along Saudi's stunning landscapes.
jeddahPage.event2Description: Feel the adrenaline at F1H2O Jeddah, where world-class drivers race high-speed boats in thrilling water battles along the Red Sea.
jeddahPage.event3Description: Experience a magical winter escape with thrilling rides, games, shows, and festive fun for all ages.

alulaPage.heroSubtitle: A timeless desert landscape home to ancient civilizations and stunning rock formations.
alulaPage.section1Para1: AlUla is one of the most significant archaeological sites in Saudi Arabia, featuring the ancient Nabataean city of Hegra (Madain Saleh), a UNESCO World Heritage Site with over 100 well-preserved tombs carved into sandstone cliffs.
alulaPage.section1Para2: The region showcases a unique blend of natural beauty and human history, with dramatic desert landscapes, ancient rock art, and modern cultural experiences that bring the past to life.
alulaPage.section1Item3: Old Town AlUla - Abandoned mudbrick village
alulaPage.section1Item5: Maraya Concert Hall - World's largest mirrored building
alulaPage.section2Subtitle: Rock facades, Nabataean tombs, and inscriptions
alulaPage.section2Para1: Hegra is the first Saudi site registered on the UNESCO World Heritage List; it features massive rock facades, carved burial chambers, and inscriptions that tell the story of Nabataean architecture and its commercial and ritual relationships.
alulaPage.section2Para2: Visits are organized through designated routes, internal buses, and certified guides, with multilingual information panels and guidelines for preserving the site's safety.
alulaPage.section2Para3: It is advisable to choose moderate times of day, wear comfortable shoes, bring water, and follow preservation guidelines, avoiding touching or climbing on the facades.
alulaPage.section2Item3: Hejaz Railway and its historic station
alulaPage.section3Subtitle: Facilitated access and integrated service system
alulaPage.section3Para1: AlUla is connected by air via AlUla Airport, and by land through modern road networks, organized parking, and internal transportation to major destinations, with interactive maps and applications for bookings and tours.
alulaPage.section3Para2: Diverse accommodation options are available, from desert lodges and scenic resorts to local guesthouses, with sustainability standards that respect environmental sensitivity.
alulaPage.section3Para3: The experience is complemented by cultural and seasonal programs, art exhibitions, and concerts on contemporary architectural platforms, within a well-organized crowd management system.
alulaPage.section3Item5: Accommodation options and local culinary experiences
alulaPage.section4Subtitle: Sunset views and strolls on the sand
alulaPage.section4Para1: This rock formation is an icon of AlUla; where golden sands extend and the sky colors at sunset. Seating areas, mobile cafes, and safe photography spaces are available that preserve the environment.
alulaPage.section4Para2: It is recommended to visit during afternoon and evening hours, and to adhere to designated paths and avoid climbing rocks for safety.
alulaPage.section5Subtitle: Alleys, market, and stepped mud-brick structure
alulaPage.section5Para1: The Old Town tells the story of settlement around the oasis: adjacent mud houses, narrow alleys, and a vibrant market with cafes and crafts. An ideal experience for walking, photography, and local tasting.
alulaPage.section6Subtitle: Ancient inscriptions and languages in one valley
alulaPage.section6Para1: Dadan reveals the remains of an ancient Arabian kingdom and distinctive obelisks, while Jabal Ikmah is known as an 'open library' of inscriptions and historical texts documenting social, religious, and linguistic affairs.
alulaPage.section6Para2: Visits are through organized tours, clear routes, and information panels that support understanding the historical context of both sites.
alulaPage.section7Para1: An architectural icon with reflective facades hosting concerts, shows, and exhibitions. The building harmonizes with the sandy and rocky formations to provide a unique visual experience.
alulaPage.section8Subtitle: Palm and citrus groves and walking under shade
alulaPage.section8Para1: The trail allows strolling through the oasis groves, its channels, and local crops, with rest stations, small markets, and farm-to-table products.
alulaPage.section9Subtitle: Hiking, hot air balloon, and countless stars
alulaPage.section9Para1: From hiking and cycling trails to hot air balloon and zipline experiences and stargazing, AlUla offers a range of activities varying between relaxation and adventure, within high safety and organization standards.
alulaPage.section10Subtitle: Local flavors and views over the valley
alulaPage.section10Para1: Options extend from seasonal local kitchens to contemporary menus with desert touches, and accommodation is distributed between lodges hidden in the valley and resorts surrounded by rock formations with stunning views.
alulaPage.event1Description: A refined dining experience under the palms, blending Mayfair elegance with local charm, featuring signature dishes and live music vibes.
alulaPage.event2Title: Hegra Drone Show - Stories from the Sky
alulaPage.event2Description: Experience a breathtaking fusion of light, sound, and storytelling as hundreds of drones light up the night sky.

aseerPage.heroSubtitle: A lush mountain region with unique architecture and cool climate.
aseerPage.section1Para1: Aseer is known for its stunning mountain landscapes, traditional architecture, and cool climate. The region offers a unique contrast to the desert landscapes found elsewhere in Saudi Arabia.
aseerPage.section1Item2: Jabal Al-Soudah - Highest peak in Saudi Arabia
aseerPage.section1Item4: Al-Qatt Al-Asiri Art - Traditional women's art
aseerPage.section2Para1: Al-Soudah is among the highest peaks in the Kingdom, offering wide views of villages and valleys with dense juniper forests and seating areas overlooking the clouds. It is an ideal destination for nature and tranquility lovers.
aseerPage.section2Para2: The area provides organized services including parking, guidance points, elevated cafes, and prepared walking paths. It also offers cable cars and mountain slides for enjoyable experiences for families and light adventure enthusiasts.
aseerPage.section2Para3: It is advisable to check weather conditions due to frequent fog, wear warm clothes in the evening, and adhere to paths to preserve the natural environment.
aseerPage.section3Subtitle: A tale of stones, colors, and arts
aseerPage.section3Para1: Rijal Almaa is one of the most prominent heritage villages in the Kingdom; its decorated stone buildings and wooden windows reveal a unique mountain architecture that reflects the region's history. Small museums, open theaters, and cafes spread through ascending alleys, in a cultural experience full of life.
aseerPage.section3Para2: It is recommended to visit the village in the afternoon and evening periods to enjoy moderate weather, with comfortable shoes and balanced walking, while maintaining the privacy of residents and site cleanliness.
aseerPage.section4Para1: Abha is the center of life in the Aseer region, distinguished by scenic parks such as Abu Khayal Park and Cloud Walk, with wide views of mountains and valleys and moderate weather throughout the year.
aseerPage.section4Para2: The city also includes the dam lake and family seating areas, in addition to cafes and restaurants with open balconies that provide a comfortable experience with attractive natural views.
aseerPage.section5Para1: Al-Muftaha Village is a vibrant arts center, where colorful murals and local exhibitions showcase the works of young artists. The neighborhood hosts cultural evenings and small theaters that give visitors a close and interactive artistic experience.
aseerPage.section5Para2: The village also includes traditional craft workshops and open photography spaces, making it an ideal place for those interested in arts, visual identity, and contemporary creative heritage in Aseer.
aseerPage.section6Para1: Aseer National Park is one of the most prominent natural sites in the region, providing walking trails and areas designated for camping, along with viewing points overlooking high peaks and deep valleys in beautiful panoramic scenes.
aseerPage.section6Para2: Information and guidance panels are spread throughout the park to ensure a safe experience, with alerts to visitors about the importance of preserving vegetation and following environmental behavior guidelines during exploration.
aseerPage.section7Subtitle: Facilitated access and natural and cultural experience
aseerPage.section7Para1: Aseer has become a connected and easily accessible region thanks to Abha Airport and road networks that link the Sarawat peaks with Tihama plains, in addition to urban walkways, organized gardens, and bike paths that provide an integrated experience for visitors.
aseerPage.section7Para2: Digital guides and interactive applications support trip planning by displaying optimal routes and locations of cultural landmarks, restaurants, and markets, facilitating confident and smooth exploration of the region.
aseerPage.section7Para3: Hospitality options vary between mountain resorts, modern hotels, and rural guesthouses, to provide comfortable accommodation with green views and experiences that combine authenticity with modernity.

alkhobarPage.heroSubtitle: A modern coastal city in the heart of Saudi Arabia's oil region.
alkhobarPage.section1Para1: Al Khobar is a key city in the Eastern Province, known for its beautiful corniche, modern business district, and proximity to major cultural attractions like the Ithra Cultural Centre.
alkhobarPage.section2Subtitle: Extended promenade, gardens, and Gulf views
alkhobarPage.section2Para1: Al Khobar Corniche extends with pedestrian and cycling paths, open gardens, and seating areas overlooking the sea, with viewing platforms, children's playgrounds, and photo spots along the blue expanse of the Gulf.
alkhobarPage.section2Para2: The waterfront features art installations and seasonal event areas, alongside restaurants and cafes with sea views and lighting paths that enhance evening stroll enjoyment.
alkhobarPage.section2Para3: The experience is integrated with organized parking solutions and safe pedestrian crossings, services for people with disabilities and the elderly, and environmental guidance that preserves beach cleanliness.
alkhobarPage.section2Para4: The paths provide easy connection between gardens, commercial areas, and light marine activity marinas.
alkhobarPage.section2Item3: Restaurants and cafes overlooking the sea
alkhobarPage.section3Subtitle: A land link between Saudi Arabia and Bahrain
alkhobarPage.section3Para1: King Fahd Causeway is one of the most important bridges in the region, connecting Al Khobar in Saudi Arabia with the Kingdom of Bahrain via a span of approximately 25 kilometers over the waters of the Arabian Gulf. The bridge was opened in 1986 to be a vital axis for tourism and commercial movement between the two countries.
alkhobarPage.section3Para2: It is recommended to check traffic conditions in advance through official applications to know the waiting time at immigration points. Travel during off-peak hours, such as early morning hours or mid-week, is preferred for a faster and smoother crossing experience.
alkhobarPage.section3Para3: The bridge provides a number of services along the route, such as immigration centers, police services, limited rest areas, in addition to the border center building that provides organized and fast procedures. The bridge is an ideal option for short trips to Bahrain, whether for relaxation, shopping, or attending weekly events.
alkhobarPage.section4Subtitle: Extended beaches and family marine activities
alkhobarPage.section4Para1: Half Moon Bay is one of the most famous beach destinations in the Eastern Province, enjoying its golden sands and calm waters extending over a long distance. The place is ideal for families and sea lovers, combining relaxation and diverse recreational activities.
alkhobarPage.section4Para2: The area has several beaches prepared for sitting and swimming, in addition to wide spaces for sports activities such as walking, cycling, and beach volleyball. Service facilities are also spread, including parking lots, shaded seating areas, restrooms, and kiosks selling fast food and beverages.
alkhobarPage.section4Para3: For adventure enthusiasts, the bay offers options such as ATV riding, Jet Ski driving, and short boat trips. The bay is also an ideal destination for overnight camping during suitable seasons.
alkhobarPage.section4Para4: It is recommended to check sea and wind conditions before visiting, especially on days of strong currents. Safety guidelines must be followed, and beach cleanliness must be maintained to ensure an enjoyable and safe experience for everyone.
alkhobarPage.section5Para1: Sultan bin Abdulaziz Science and Technology Center (Scitech) is one of the most prominent scientific destinations in the Eastern Province, offering an interactive educational experience that combines fun and knowledge for all ages. The center is distinguished by its rotating exhibitions that introduce visitors to the basics of modern science, technology, space, and energy.
alkhobarPage.section5Para2: The center houses more than 350 interactive scientific experiments distributed across various halls, including physics, robotics, senses, technology, environment, and marine science exhibitions. It also provides educational shows in the Scitech Science Dome (IMAX) with massive display technologies and enjoyable visual content.
alkhobarPage.section5Para3: The center is an ideal destination for students and families, offering workshops and training programs designed for children and adolescents to develop thinking, creativity, and discovery skills. In addition, it hosts scientific events and competitions throughout the year.
alkhobarPage.section5Para4: The center is located near the waterfront in Al Khobar, making it a wonderful part of a complete family trip that combines education and entertainment. It is preferable to check the schedule of events and show times before visiting to ensure the best experience.
alkhobarPage.section6Para1: King Abdulaziz World Cultural Center "Ithra" is one of the most prominent cultural landmarks in the Kingdom, combining art, creativity, education, and interactive experiences under one roof. The center includes diverse museums, global exhibition halls, a huge library containing thousands of books, in addition to a modern cinema and halls dedicated to workshops, courses, and creativity.
alkhobarPage.section6Para2: Ithra is distinguished by its unique engineering design that has become one of the icons of the Eastern Province, and it hosts throughout the year cultural events, theatrical performances, festivals, and educational programs for children and adults, making it an ideal destination for families and lovers of culture and arts.
alkhobarPage.section6Para3: The center provides interactive experiences such as the Innovation Lab, Energy Exhibition, and Natural History Exhibition, in addition to spaces dedicated to modern and contemporary arts. Visitors can also enjoy diverse restaurants and cafes inside the building.
alkhobarPage.section6Para4: Ithra is located minutes away from Al Khobar city, and it is preferable to check the schedule of events and temporary exhibitions before visiting to ensure benefiting from the available experiences on the day of visit.
alkhobarPage.section7Subtitle: Facilitated access, smart services, and coastal urban experience
alkhobarPage.section7Para1: Al Khobar is connected to the world via King Fahd International Airport (Dammam), and to neighboring cities via a modern road network and the nearby Dammam train station, making access to the waterfront and entertainment destinations easy and smooth.
alkhobarPage.section7Para2: Applications and interactive maps support visit planning, from parking to events and restaurants, with real-time updates and multilingual guidance guides.
alkhobarPage.section7Para3: The city offers a mix of upscale hospitality, major shopping centers, and sports and marine activities, in an urban scene connected with Dhahran and Dammam.

firstState.title: The First Saudi State
firstState.subtitle: 1139-1233 AH / 1727-1818 CE
firstState.para1: The Arabian Peninsula in the early 12th century AH (18th century CE) was in a state of chaos and political instability. Historians described the political and social conditions in the Arabian Peninsula during that period as fragmented, insecure, with numerous scattered and conflicting emirates.
firstState.para2: In 1139 AH (1727 CE), the First Saudi State was founded by Imam Muhammad bin Saud, with Diriyah as its capital in the heart of the Arabian Peninsula.
firstState.para3: The imams of the First Saudi State succeeded in unifying most regions of the Arabian Peninsula and ushering in a new era characterized by stability, security, and the application of Islamic law in all aspects of life. As a result of the establishment of the Saudi State, many scholars emerged, and knowledge, scientific, and economic aspects flourished.
firstState.para4: Many institutions and administrative systems were established. The First Saudi State enjoyed great political status due to its strength and Islamic principles, its vast geographical expanse, and the balanced policies of its rulers based on supporting Islam and serving society and elevating its civilizational level. The First Saudi State ended in 1233 AH (1818 CE) as a result of campaigns sent by the Ottoman Empire through its governor in Egypt, Muhammad Ali, the last of which was Ibrahim Pasha's campaign that succeeded in destroying Diriyah and many towns in the regions of the First Saudi State throughout the Arabian Peninsula.
firstState.rulersTitle: Rulers of the First Saudi State
firstState.ruler1: Imam Muhammad bin Saud bin Muqrin (1139-1179 AH / 1727-1765 CE)
firstState.ruler2: Imam Abdulaziz bin Muhammad bin Saud (1179-1218 AH / 1765-1803 CE)
firstState.ruler3: Imam Saud bin Abdulaziz bin Muhammad bin Saud (1218-1229 AH / 1803-1814 CE)
firstState.ruler4: Imam Abdullah bin Saud bin Abdulaziz bin Muhammad bin Saud (1229-1233 AH / 1814-1818 CE)

secondState.title: The Second Saudi State
secondState.subtitle: 1240-1309 AH / 1824-1891 CE
secondState.para1: Despite the destruction and devastation left by Muhammad Ali's forces under the leadership of Ibrahim Pasha in central Arabia, the destruction of Diriyah and many towns, and the spread of fear throughout the Arabian Peninsula, they were unable to eliminate the foundations of the Saudi State. The people in both the desert and settled areas remained loyal to the House of Saud, which founded the First Saudi State, appreciating their treatment and wise leadership, and supporting the Salafi call. Not two years had passed since the end of the First Saudi State before the leaders from the House of Saud reappeared to re-establish the Saudi State.
secondState.para2: Their first attempt was in 1235 AH / 1820 CE when Prince Mishari bin Saud attempted to restore Saudi rule in Diriyah, but it lasted only a short period not exceeding a few months. This was followed by a successful attempt led by Imam Turki bin Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Saud in 1240 AH / 1824 CE, which led to the establishment of the Second Saudi State with Riyadh as its capital.
secondState.para3: The Second Saudi State continued on the same foundations and pillars as the First Saudi State in terms of reliance on Islam, spreading security and stability, and applying Islamic law. The administrative and financial systems were similar to those in the First Saudi State, and sciences and literature flourished under the Second Saudi State.
secondState.para4: In 1309 AH / 1891 CE, Imam Abdulrahman bin Faisal bin Turki left Riyadh following disagreements among the sons of Imam Faisal bin Turki, and the control of Muhammad bin Rashid, the ruler of Hail, over it. Thus ended the Second Saudi State.
secondState.rulersTitle: Rulers of the Second Saudi State
secondState.ruler1: Imam Turki bin Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Saud (1240-1249 AH / 1824-1834 CE)
secondState.ruler2: Imam Faisal bin Turki. First Period (1250-1254 AH / 1834-1838 CE)
secondState.ruler4: Imam Abdullah bin Faisal bin Turki. First Period (1282-1288 AH / 1865-1871 CE)
secondState.ruler5: Imam Saud bin Faisal bin Turki (1288-1291 AH / 1871-1875 CE)
secondState.ruler6: Imam Abdulrahman bin Faisal bin Turki. First Period (1291-1293 AH / 1875-1876 CE)
secondState.ruler7: Imam Abdullah bin Faisal bin Turki – Second Period (1293-1305 AH / 1876-1878 CE)

modernKingdom.title: Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
modernKingdom.subtitle: 1319 AH - Present / 1902 CE - Present
modernKingdom.para1: On the fifth of Shawwal 1319 AH, corresponding to the fifteenth of January (1902 CE), King Abdulaziz bin Abdulrahman bin Faisal Al Saud succeeded in recapturing Riyadh and returning with his family to begin a new page in Saudi history. This historical event marked a major turning point in the region's history, leading to the establishment of a modern Saudi state that succeeded in unifying most parts of the Arabian Peninsula and achieving wide-ranging civilizational achievements in various fields.
modernKingdom.para2: King Abdulaziz was given several titles during his reign, in addition to the title of Imam:
modernKingdom.title1: Prince of Najd and Chief of its Tribes 1319 AH (1902 CE)
modernKingdom.title3: Sultan of Najd and its Dependencies 1340 AH (1922 CE)
modernKingdom.title4: King of Hejaz and Sultan of Najd and its Dependencies 1345 AH (1927 CE)
modernKingdom.title5: King of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia 1351 AH (1932 CE)
modernKingdom.para3: On the seventeenth of Jumada al-Awwal 1351 AH, corresponding to the nineteenth of September 1932 CE, a royal decree was issued to announce the unification of the country and naming it the "Kingdom of Saudi Arabia", starting from Thursday, the 21st of Jumada al-Awwal 1351 AH, corresponding to September 23, 1932 CE (the first of Libra).

kingAbdulaziz.title: King Abdulaziz bin Abdulrahman Al Saud
kingAbdulaziz.subtitle: Founder of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
kingAbdulaziz.para1: This announcement crowned King Abdulaziz's great efforts to unify the country and establish a solid state based on the application of the provisions of the Quran and the noble Sunnah. The first day of Libra, corresponding to the twenty-third of September, was designated to become the National Day of the Kingdom. With this announcement, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia was established, which became a great state in message, achievements, and regional and international status.
kingAbdulaziz.para2: The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia during the reign of King Abdulaziz gained special international status, joining many international organizations and agreements, due to its great location and solidity. It was among the first countries to sign the United Nations Charter in 1364 AH (1945 CE) and contributed to the establishment of many international organizations aimed at establishing security, stability, and international justice, such as the League of Arab States in 1364 AH (1945 CE).
kingAbdulaziz.afterTitle: The Journey of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia After King Abdulaziz's Reign
kingAbdulaziz.para3: After the death of King Abdulaziz – may God have mercy on him – on the second of Rabi' al-Awwal 1373 AH, corresponding to the ninth of November 1953 CE, his sons followed his path and completed the foundation and building according to the lofty principles on which the Saudi state is based. After King Abdulaziz, his sons ruled as kings:

kingSaud.title: King Saud bin Abdulaziz
kingSaud.subtitle: 1373-1384 AH (1953 – 1964)
kingSaud.para: He was pledged allegiance as king of the country. During his reign, building was completed and the march of development continued in various aspects. King Saud was keen to make many internal visits at the beginning of his reign to inspect the country, and external visits to strengthen ties of cooperation with neighboring and friendly countries. King Saud gave special attention to Arab and Islamic issues, continuing the approach of King Abdulaziz and the Saudi state.

kingFaisal.title: King Faisal bin Abdulaziz
kingFaisal.subtitle: 1384-1395 AH (1964-1975 CE)
kingFaisal.para: He was pledged allegiance as king of the country in 1384 AH (1964 CE) after his brother King Saud's abdication, and continued the building march that his father King Abdulaziz began and his brother King Saud completed. The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia witnessed many developments in various fields during King Faisal's reign, and became a leader in international meetings, Arab and Islamic summits due to its international status and noble message. In facing major blocs and the spread of misleading ideas and principles, King Faisal succeeded in directing Arab and Islamic efforts under the leadership of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, which became a fundamental pillar in international politics.

kingKhalid.title: King Khalid bin Abdulaziz
kingKhalid.subtitle: 1395-1402 AH (1975 – 1982 CE)
kingKhalid.para: He was pledged allegiance as king of the country in 1395 AH (1975 CE) following the martyrdom of King Faisal, to continue the march of development and building in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The country witnessed significant development in various fields of development during his reign, through benefiting from civilizational achievements while maintaining the constants of the Saudi state and its distinguished Islamic approach. The Kingdom continued during his reign to be at the top of Arab and Islamic policies, as it is a state firmly established in its leadership and principles, and hosts the Two Holy Mosques, the destination of Muslim hearts.

kingFahd.title: King Fahd bin Abdulaziz (Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques)
kingFahd.subtitle: 1402 AH (1982 CE) – 1426 AH (2005 CE)
kingFahd.para1: In 1402 AH (1982 CE), the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques King Fahd bin Abdulaziz assumed power, guided by the approach of his father King Abdulaziz in building the state and society, and advancing them toward the highest civilizational levels.
kingFahd.para2: The reign of King Fahd bin Abdulaziz witnessed great civilizational achievements reflected in the country's progress, the prosperity of life, the continuation of applying Islamic law, and attention to security and scientific aspects. The Kingdom also continued its development and progress in industrial fields as a result of his policies and care for comprehensive development plans and the establishment of the industrial infrastructure in the Kingdom.
kingFahd.para3: During his reign, the largest historical expansion of the Two Holy Mosques occurred, and the economic, social, and civilizational levels in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia reached their highest degrees. Saudi foreign policy during the reign of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques King Fahd bin Abdulaziz was characterized by effectiveness and realism, and formulating appropriate solutions for the most important Arab and Islamic issues.

kingAbdullah.title: King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz Al Saud
kingAbdullah.subtitle: 1426 AH (2005 CE) - 1436 AH (2015 CE)
kingAbdullah.para1: On Wednesday, the 28th of Jumada al-Thani 1426 AH (3/8/2005 CE), he was pledged allegiance as king of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz supported Islamic solidarity, deepened fraternal bonds between Arab countries, and played an active role in bridging gaps in the Arab ranks, in addition to his active role in the global economy, the United Nations, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), and non-aligned countries, as well as his generous contributions in local and humanitarian charitable works, supporting science and scholars, developing education, and establishing financial and scientific technical institutions.
kingAbdullah.para2: He visited many Arab, Islamic, and friendly countries in Asia, Europe, America, and Africa, attended many Arab and Islamic summit conferences, and was keen on achieving peace in the Arab region.
kingAbdullah.para3: His reign witnessed many achievements in the fields of higher education, general education, judiciary, health, expansion of the Prophet's Mosque, expansion of the Grand Mosque, and expansion of the Tawaf area.

kingSalman.title: King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud
kingSalman.subtitle: 1436 AH (2015 CE) - Present
kingSalman.para1: The Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud, may God protect him, was pledged allegiance as king of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia on 3 Rabi' al-Thani 1436 AH, corresponding to January 23, 2015 CE. King Salman had spent more than two and a half years as Crown Prince and Deputy Prime Minister after his appointment on June 18, 2012 CE by royal decree, while remaining in his position as Minister of Defense, a position he had held since November 5, 2011 CE. Before that, King Salman was the Governor of Riyadh Region for more than fifty years.
kingSalman.para2: The Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques is known for his care for heritage and attention to the country's history, alongside his distinguished efforts in development and advancement in the country. He has also contributed to various humanitarian fields within and outside the Kingdom, especially in the areas of relief and assistance.
